The Optimization Landscape of SGD
Across the Feature Learning Strength

Alexander Atanasovâˆ—,1,2,4, Alexandru Meterezâˆ—,2, James B Simon ,3,5, Cengiz Pehlevan2,4,6
1 Department of Physics, Harvard University
2 School of Engineering and Applied Science, Harvard University
3 Department of Physics, University of California, Berkeley
4 Center for Brain Science, Harvard University
5 Imbue
6 Kempner Institute, Harvard University
{atanasov,cpehlevan}@g.harvard.edu Joint first authorship, alphabetized
Abstract

We consider neural networks (NNs) where the final layer is down-scaled by a fixed hyperparameter Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³. Recent work has identified Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ as controlling the strength of feature learning. As Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ increases, network evolution changes from â€œlazyâ€ kernel dynamics to â€œrichâ€ feature-learning dynamics, with a host of associated benefits including improved performance on common tasks. In this work, we conduct a thorough empirical investigation of the effect of scaling Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ across a variety of models and datasets in the online training setting. We first examine the interaction of Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ with the learning rate Î·ğœ‚\etaitalic_Î·, identifying several scaling regimes in the Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³-Î·ğœ‚\etaitalic_Î· plane which we explain theoretically using a simple model. We find that the optimal learning rate Î·âˆ—superscriptğœ‚\eta^{*}italic_Î· start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT scales non-trivially with Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³. In particular, Î·âˆ—âˆÎ³2proportional-tosuperscriptğœ‚superscriptğ›¾2\eta^{*}\propto\gamma^{2}italic_Î· start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ italic_Î³ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT when Î³â‰ª1much-less-thanğ›¾1\gamma\ll 1italic_Î³ â‰ª 1 and Î·âˆ—âˆÎ³2/Lproportional-tosuperscriptğœ‚superscriptğ›¾2ğ¿\eta^{*}\propto\gamma^{2/L}italic_Î· start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ italic_Î³ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 / italic_L end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT when Î³â‰«1much-greater-thanğ›¾1\gamma\gg 1italic_Î³ â‰« 1 for a feed-forward network of depth Lğ¿Litalic_L. Using this optimal learning rate scaling, we proceed with an empirical study of the under-explored â€œultra-richâ€ Î³â‰«1much-greater-thanğ›¾1\gamma\gg 1italic_Î³ â‰« 1 regime. We find that networks in this regime display characteristic loss curves, starting with a long plateau followed by a drop-off, sometimes followed by one or more additional staircase steps. We find networks of different large Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ values optimize along similar trajectories up to a reparameterization of time. We further find that optimal online performance is often found at large Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ and could be missed if this hyperparameter is not tuned. Our findings indicate that analytical study of the large-Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ limit may yield useful insights into the dynamics of representation learning in performant models.

1 Introduction

The study of large-width limits of neural networks (NNs) has led to a variety of insights about deep learning. As network width Nğ‘Nitalic_N tends to infinity, networks in either â€œPyTorch standardâ€ parameterization or neural tangent kernel (NTK) parameterization converge to kernel methods Jacot et al. (2018); Lee et al. (2019); Sohl-Dickstein et al. (2020). Kernel methods have a fixed set of features, and networks in this kernel limit have fixed representations at each layer over training. By contrast, realistic neural networks adapt their features during the course of training Fort et al. (2020); Vyas et al. (2022); Lee et al. (2020). Feature learning is widely believed to be intimately connected to the excellent performance of NNs on practical tasks.

If one takes a centered NN111In this paper, we assume all networks are centered, meaning that fâ¢(ğ’™;ğœ½)=0ğ‘“ğ’™ğœ½0f(\bm{x};\bm{\theta})=0italic_f ( bold_italic_x ; bold_italic_Î¸ ) = 0 at initialization. This can be achieved by subtracting a non-trainable copy of the network at initialization. fâ¢(ğ’™;ğœ½)ğ‘“ğ’™ğœ½f(\bm{x};\bm{\theta})italic_f ( bold_italic_x ; bold_italic_Î¸ ) in NTK parameterization with inputs ğ’™ğ’™\bm{x}bold_italic_x and parameters ğœ½ğœ½\bm{\theta}bold_italic_Î¸ and scales the output as f~â¢(ğ’™;ğœ½)â‰¡Î±â¢fâ¢(ğ’™;ğœ½)~ğ‘“ğ’™ğœ½ğ›¼ğ‘“ğ’™ğœ½\tilde{f}(\bm{x};\bm{\theta})\equiv\alpha f(\bm{x};\bm{\theta})over~ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG ( bold_italic_x ; bold_italic_Î¸ ) â‰¡ italic_Î± italic_f ( bold_italic_x ; bold_italic_Î¸ ), one can control the degree to which the NN learns features. Taking Î±â†’âˆâ†’ğ›¼\alpha\to\inftyitalic_Î± â†’ âˆ yields the â€œlazy limit,â€ where the network behaves as a kernel Chizat et al. (2019). By contrast, if one sets Î±=(Î³â¢N)âˆ’1ğ›¼superscriptğ›¾ğ‘1\alpha=(\gamma\sqrt{N})^{-1}italic_Î± = ( italic_Î³ square-root start_ARG italic_N end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for fixed Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ and simultaneously scales the learning rate as Î·â¢Nğœ‚ğ‘\eta Nitalic_Î· italic_N, one obtains a network whose hidden representations evolve even at infinite width (Geiger et al., 2020; Mei et al., 2018; Rotskoff & Vanden-Eijnden, 2018; Yang & Hu, 2021; Bordelon & Pehlevan, 2022), a scaling termed the â€œmaximal update parameterizationâ€ or â€œÎ¼ğœ‡\muitalic_Î¼Pâ€ by Yang & Hu (2021). Although at practical widths and dataset scales, NNs in standard and NTK parameterization deviate from their infinite-width kernel limit Lee et al. (2020), networks in Î¼ğœ‡\muitalic_Î¼P achieve their infinite width behavior at realistic scales Vyas et al. (2023a); Noci et al. (2024). Networks parameterized in Î¼ğœ‡\muitalic_Î¼P generally achieve better performance, and Î¼ğœ‡\muitalic_Î¼P can be utilized effectively for zero-shot hyperparameter transfer from small models to large Yang et al. (2021); Bordelon et al. (2023). The width does not affect the degree of feature learning in Î¼ğœ‡\muitalic_Î¼P, so we identify Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ as the feature learning strength or richness parameter Woodworth et al. (2020).

This story leaves Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ as a free hyperparameter to be tuned, but despite its importance, little is practically known about the effects of varying Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³. In this paper, we perform a thorough scaling analysis in which we train a variety of deep networks with Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ ranging across many orders of magnitude, with an eye towards both optimal tuning of Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ and cataloging the diverse dynamical phenomena that occur in different hyperparameter regimes. In addition to studying the lazy (Î³â‰ª1much-less-thanğ›¾1\gamma\ll 1italic_Î³ â‰ª 1) and rich (Î³âˆ¼1similar-toğ›¾1\gamma\sim 1italic_Î³ âˆ¼ 1) regimes, we pay particular attention to what we term the ultra-rich (Î³â‰«1much-greater-thanğ›¾1\gamma\gg 1italic_Î³ â‰« 1) regime.

In this work, we focus on the online setting, where a fresh batch of data is given at each step and we train for a fixed time set by a compute budget. This is realistic of modern large-scale language and vision models and is scientifically clarifying, removing the confounding effect of finite dataset size.

Concretely our contributions are as follows. We systematically vary Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ over a suite of models spanning MLPs, CNNs, ResNets, and Vision Transformers (ViTs) on a variety of datasets. In all settings:

  • â€¢

    Sweeping over both Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ and the learning rate Î·ğœ‚\etaitalic_Î·, we observe a characteristic phase portrait of model performance in the Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³-Î·ğœ‚\etaitalic_Î· plane, which depends only on the choice of the loss function and not the model architecture (Figure 1). We show that the optimal learning rate scales as Î·âˆ—âˆ¼Î³2similar-tosubscriptğœ‚superscriptğ›¾2\eta_{*}\sim\gamma^{2}italic_Î· start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¼ italic_Î³ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in the lazy (Î³â‰ª1much-less-thanğ›¾1\gamma\ll 1italic_Î³ â‰ª 1) regime and Î·âˆ—âˆ¼Î³2/Lsimilar-tosubscriptğœ‚superscriptğ›¾2ğ¿\eta_{*}\sim\gamma^{2/L}italic_Î· start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¼ italic_Î³ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 / italic_L end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, where Lğ¿Litalic_L is the model depth, in the ultra-rich (Î³â‰«1much-greater-thanğ›¾1\gamma\gg 1italic_Î³ â‰« 1) regime. Our phase portrait reveals an upper limit on Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ for a deep network to be optimizable for a given compute budget.

  • â€¢

    After adopting the correct learning rate scaling, we find that large Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ networks usually exceed or match the performance of naive Î³=1ğ›¾1\gamma=1italic_Î³ = 1 networks if trained for sufficiently long (Figure 2). This disagrees with findings in the offline training setting Petrini et al. (2022), where strong feature learning was found to degrade performance.

  • â€¢

    At small Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³, we observe the scaling of Î·ğœ‚\etaitalic_Î· with Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ predicted by kernel theory. To our knowledge, we are the first to observe that transformer-based architectures on large datasets can empirically reach the lazy limit. At slightly-too-large Î·ğœ‚\etaitalic_Î· in the lazy (Î³â‰ª1much-less-thanğ›¾1\gamma\ll 1italic_Î³ â‰ª 1) regime, we observe the â€œcatapult effectâ€ of Lewkowycz et al. (2020) in which the loss quickly grows large before gradually converging. We see catapults for Î³2â‰²Î·â‰²Î³less-than-or-similar-tosuperscriptğ›¾2ğœ‚less-than-or-similar-toğ›¾\gamma^{2}\lesssim\eta\lesssim\gammaitalic_Î³ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰² italic_Î· â‰² italic_Î³ for cross-entropy loss, but only in a narrow band around Î·âˆ¼Î³2similar-toğœ‚superscriptğ›¾2\eta\sim\gamma^{2}italic_Î· âˆ¼ italic_Î³ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for MSE. Smaller Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ leads to larger catapults.

  • â€¢

    At large Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³, we observe silent alignment as in Atanasov et al. (2022): at early times, the kernel aligns itself to the task before the loss drops. During this early period, NNs exhibit strikingly similar dynamics upon rescaling Ï„=Î·â¢t/Î³ğœğœ‚ğ‘¡ğ›¾\tau=\eta t/\gammaitalic_Ï„ = italic_Î· italic_t / italic_Î³, with the loss often exhibiting step-wise drops as in Saxe et al. (2014); Simon et al. (2023b) even in very realistic networks. We further observe that the loss drops at the end of silent alignment coincide with the Hessian growth predicted by the edge of stability (EOS; Cohen et al. (2021)).

  • â€¢

    At optimal learning rate, we see a surprising agreement in the loss trajectories of large-Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ networks at late times in training. This suggests that large-Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ networks are learning similar features and functions past a certain threshold. We verify this similarity by comparing losses, accuracies, learned functions, and internal representations.

  • â€¢

    Finally, we reproduce and analytically derive our phase portrait and many of the above behaviors in the simple setting of a linear neural network model (Section 4). There, we show the modified Î·ğœ‚\etaitalic_Î· scaling in the large Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ regime is due to a progressive sharpening effect.

We review the catapult, silent alignment, and progressive sharpening effects in Appendix C.

1.1 Related Works

Chizat et al. (2019) introduced the laziness parameter Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± in their seminal work. Mei et al. (2018); Rotskoff & Vanden-Eijnden (2018) introduced networks in mean-field parameterization. Geiger et al. (2020) introduced the correct scaling of Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± with Nğ‘Nitalic_N as Î±=(Î³â¢N)âˆ’1ğ›¼superscriptğ›¾ğ‘1\alpha=(\gamma\sqrt{N})^{-1}italic_Î± = ( italic_Î³ square-root start_ARG italic_N end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to achieve feature learning at infinite width. They also highlighted that Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ can be identified as the parameter that controls feature learning. Yang & Hu (2021) expanded this idea to deep networks of arbitrary architecture and coined the term Î¼ğœ‡\muitalic_Î¼P. Bordelon & Pehlevan (2022) described this limit in terms of dynamical mean field theory. Extensions to infinite depth were performed in Bordelon et al. (2023) and Yang et al. (2023b) and to infinite attention in Bordelon et al. (2024c). We give a review of network parameterizations in Appendix B. A key motivation for this work is that Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ is the main free parameter in the DMFT description of infinite-width feature learning networks, warranting a more thorough empirical investigation.

The question of optimal Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ was explored in the paper of Petrini et al. (2022). There, for several models in the offline setting, they showed large Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ networks performed worse. In a linear network toy model, Pesme et al. (2021) showed that SGD noise could be absorbed into a rescaling of Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±. Sclocchi et al. (2023) performed a large set of thorough experiments to study the interplay between the SGD noise in different regimes of Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ and find that SGD noise can hurt or help in the offline setting. By contrast to these papers, we focus on the online setting. We comment on this further in Section 2.1. Under cross-entropy loss, Agarwala et al. (2020) performed extensive sweeps on un-centered networks over Î³,Î·ğ›¾ğœ‚\gamma,\etaitalic_Î³ , italic_Î·, identifying Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ as the soft-max temperature, similarly finding that slightly larger Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ achieves top performance. Our cross-entropy results overlap with this work and recover their findings, but we additionally identify a different way to scale Î·ğœ‚\etaitalic_Î· at large Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³, allowing us to probe the very rich limits without training instability.

Various analytical studies of the large-Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ limit have been performed in the setting of linear networks Atanasov et al. (2022); Tu et al. (2024), with Jacot et al. (2021) terming this limit the â€œsaddle-to-saddleâ€ regime. The feature learning parameter has been shown to play a key role in the mechanism for grokking in Kumar et al. (2024). The paper of Kalra et al. (2023) performed a thorough analysis of the causes of progressive sharpening and catapult behavior in networks across Î¼ğœ‡\muitalic_Î¼P and SP in the offline setting. In the online setting we show that all effects are present in Î¼ğœ‡\muitalic_Î¼P and are modulated by the Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ parameter. In the setting of a linear network, Marion & Chizat (2024) also found a nontrivial and depth-dependent sharpening effect. Earlier works studying the effect of varying the Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ parameter Sclocchi et al. (2023); Bordelon & Pehlevan (2022; 2023) focused on the offline setting of training with repeated data until some convergence criterion is satisfied.

We will consider both mean-squared-error and cross-entropy loss for â„“â„“\ellroman_â„“. In this work we focus on optimizing the parameters by vanilla SGD, as even in this simple setting, the effect of Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ is not well-understood. For small batch sizes, the the SGD effects are controlled by the ratio Î·/Bğœ‚ğµ\eta/Bitalic_Î· / italic_B Jastrzebski et al. (2017); Smith et al. (2020); Sclocchi et al. (2023). We verify this this in Appendix H.

We study networks trained on the datasets, MNIST, CIFAR and TinyImageNet. Our motivation is to study networks training in the online setting over several orders of magnitude in time. To this end, we adopt larger versions of these datasets: â€œMNIST-1Mâ€ and CIFAR-5M, and apply strong data augmentation to TinyImagenet. We generate MNIST-1M using the denoising diffusion model Ho et al. (2020) in Pearce (2022). We use CIFAR-5M from Nakkiran et al. (2021). Earlier results in Refinetti et al. (2023) show that networks trained on CIFAR-5M have very similar trajectories to those trained on CIFAR-10 without repetition.

2.1 Why Train Online?

In the modern era of large models, the full training set is seldom repeated Kaplan et al. (2020); Muennighoff et al. (2023). Online, the effect of SGD noise was seen to have negligible effect on scaling both empirically Vyas et al. (2023b) and theoretically Paquette et al. (2024). The online setting thus allows us to isolate properties of Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ as an optimization hyperparameter for the population gradient flow that SGD approximates. This removes the complicated overfitting effects that have been theoretically shown to build up when data is repeated Bordelon et al. (2024a), as well as the many regimes of SGD under an interpolation constraint Sclocchi & Wyart (2024).

3 Empirical Results

In this section we consider a variety of architectures: MLPs, CNNs, ResNet-18s, and Vision Transformers (ViTs), trained on a variety of tasks. We first discuss the different regimes observed in the Î·ğœ‚\etaitalic_Î·-Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ plane across architectures. We then discuss the properties of the Hessian, and identify specific dynamical phenomena. Finally, we focus on the large Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ limit and show that learned functions learned representations largely agree across large Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ networks.

3.1 Phase Portrait of Î·ğœ‚\etaitalic_Î· with Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³

We begin by considering the Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³-Î·ğœ‚\etaitalic_Î· plane for a variety of architectures and datasets. We sweep jointly over every pair of Î·,Î³ğœ‚ğ›¾\eta,\gammaitalic_Î· , italic_Î³ in a log-spaced grid running from Î³=10âˆ’5ğ›¾superscript105\gamma=10^{-5}italic_Î³ = 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to 105superscript10510^{5}10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. For each Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³, we sweep from Î·=1012ğœ‚superscript1012\eta=10^{12}italic_Î· = 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 12 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to Î·=10âˆ’12ğœ‚superscript1012\eta=10^{-12}italic_Î· = 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 12 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT downwards in a log-spaced grid until the first convergent Î·ğœ‚\etaitalic_Î· is reached. After finding the first convergent Î·ğœ‚\etaitalic_Î·, we sweep over a range of Î·ğœ‚\etaitalic_Î· below it. We consider both MSE and cross-entropy losses. Further details are given in Appendix A.

At small Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³, Î·âˆÎ³2proportional-toğœ‚superscriptğ›¾2\eta\propto\gamma^{2}italic_Î· âˆ italic_Î³ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for lazy networks

We see this on the left region of the plots in Figure 1 and 1. We verify that networks of different but sufficiently small Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ have the same loss dynamics in Appendix I.1, indicating that the lazy limit is reached by realistic networks.

At small Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ and larger Î·ğœ‚\etaitalic_Î·, catapults can occur

For Î·ğœ‚\etaitalic_Î· larger than the sharpness allowed by convex optimization, the loss explodes early on in time. For a range of Î·ğœ‚\etaitalic_Î· above this, the loss eventually drops again. This is the catapult effect of Lewkowycz et al. (2020). The maximal learning rate for these scales as Î³2superscriptğ›¾2\gamma^{2}italic_Î³ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT under MSE loss and as Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ under cross-entropy loss. We revisit this in Section 3.3 and Figure 4.

At large Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³, there are two learning rate scalings

Empirically, in Figures 1 and 1, we observe a â€œtriangle of optimizabilityâ€ in the large Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ limit. To our knowledge prior works have not highlighted this fact. The upper boundary of the maximal learning rate before the loss explodes is found empirically to scale as Î·âˆ¼Î³2/Lsimilar-toğœ‚superscriptğ›¾2ğ¿\eta\sim\gamma^{2/L}italic_Î· âˆ¼ italic_Î³ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 / italic_L end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. On the other hand, at large Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³, activation movement precedes function movement, by contrast to the lazy limit. The minimal learning rate scaling in order for the activations to move by Î˜Î³â¢(1)subscriptÎ˜ğ›¾1\Theta_{\gamma}(1)roman_Î˜ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î³ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 1 ) is Î·âˆ¼Î³similar-toğœ‚ğ›¾\eta\sim\gammaitalic_Î· âˆ¼ italic_Î³, as in Bordelon & Pehlevan (2022), or Î·âˆ¼Î³/Tsimilar-toğœ‚ğ›¾ğ‘‡\eta\sim\gamma/Titalic_Î· âˆ¼ italic_Î³ / italic_T under a budget of Tğ‘‡Titalic_T training steps. Taking CâˆTâ¢Bproportional-toğ¶ğ‘‡ğµC\propto TBitalic_C âˆ italic_T italic_B to be the compute budget, we see that generally increasing Cğ¶Citalic_C increases the optimizable region for large Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³.

Sufficiently large Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ NNs see improved scaling laws

We plot the loss in time across Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ in Figure 2. We overlay two different scaling curves as dashed lines. We see the slopes between the small Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ lazy networks and the large Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ rich networks appear substantively different. The former slope can be predicted from kernel theory, as in Pillaud-Vivien et al. (2018) and Bordelon & Pehlevan (2021). Increasing Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ beyond some threshold does not appear to improve the scaling law. This echoes similar findings as found by the recent model of Bordelon et al. (2024b).

Large-Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ NNs achieve good generalization, given sufficient training time

We plot the accuracy of NNs across Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ in Figure 2. We see that generalization improves with larger Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³, eventually reaching a roughly constant value. This contrasts with studies in the offline setting Geiger et al. (2020); Sclocchi et al. (2023) where performance decreases at large Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³. We highlight that if networks do not train long enough, a non-monotonicity is indeed present, but this goes away with longer online training.

Here, we have split the Hessian into a Gauss-Newton term ğ’¢ğ’¢\mathcal{G}caligraphic_G and a loss gradient term â„›â„›\mathcal{R}caligraphic_R. The Hessian contains important properties about the optimization landscape. One particularly important quantity is top eigenvalue Î»mâ¢aâ¢xsubscriptğœ†ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥\lambda_{max}italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_a italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, also known as the sharpness. The sharpness governs the maximal allowable learning rate in a convex optimization problem.

Across all tasks we find remarkably consistent behavior of the Hessian spectrum, see Figure 3. For Î³â‰ª1much-less-thanğ›¾1\gamma\ll 1italic_Î³ â‰ª 1, the network stays lazy and the Hessian does not evolve. Once Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ exceeds a threshold however, we observe a distinct change in scaling at the end of training. For feed-forward MLPs and CNNs, we verify a scaling going as Î³âˆ’2/Lsuperscriptğ›¾2ğ¿\gamma^{-2/L}italic_Î³ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 2 / italic_L end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. In section 4, we derive this scaling in a linear network model.

We also track how the top eigenvalues of the evolve in time in Figures 3, 3 and 3. For lazy networks we predictably see no evolution. In the next section we show that small Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ but larger Î·ğœ‚\etaitalic_Î· networks can catapult and lower their sharpness. For rich networks we highlight that a very extensive number of eigenvalues grow to large scale. This is in contrast with the commonly observed phenomenon that for a Cğ¶Citalic_C-class classification task there should be Cğ¶Citalic_C outliers. Here, in the lazy limit there are indeed 10101010 distinct outliers, but in the rich regime there are no distinct outliers at late times.

3.3 Dynamical Phenomena

We here describe a catalog of different dynamical phenomena that we find in networks trained in the small- and large-Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ regimes. We give background on these effects in Appendix C.

The catapult effect at small Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³

We see in Figure 4 that small Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ networks exhibit large increases followed by decreases in the loss, with remarkably regular behavior, decreasing in scale as Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ grows. In Appendix D, we leverage a similar linear network model to arrive at the desired catapult scalings with Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ under both MSE and cross-entropy loss.

Silent alignment at large Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³

We now consider the dynamics at large Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³. Empirically, we find that our sweeps do not detect any catapult effects once Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ is large enough. Taking the optimal learning rate for SGD at large Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ still yields a long loss plateau. During this plateau, the NN can be shown to be adapting its features, and appears to align its hidden-layer representations with the task. We illustrate this in Figure 4. This effect was identified in linear networks at small initialization in Atanasov et al. (2022), and shown to empirically hold in a restricted class of NNs on whitened data. Here, we show that it arises in a much broader class of realistic settings.

Stepwise loss drops at large Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³

At very large Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³, we often observe loss trajectories following a characteristic staircase pattern, with one or more plateaus punctuated by sudden drops. This is a prediction of linear network theory Saxe et al. (2014); Simon et al. (2023a) that seems to hold even for very realistic models. We see these step-wise trajectories for MLPS in Figures 4, 27 and 35, CNNs in Figures 27 and 34 and ViTs in Figure 12. We show that, upon rescaling time as Ï„=Î·â¢t/Î³ğœğœ‚ğ‘¡ğ›¾\tau=\eta t/\gammaitalic_Ï„ = italic_Î· italic_t / italic_Î³, the early time dynamics coincide. The first loss drop goes as tâˆ¼Î³similar-toğ‘¡ğ›¾t\sim\gammaitalic_t âˆ¼ italic_Î³. We explain the origin of this timescale in Section 4.

Progressive sharpening at the end of silent alignment

Across all tasks and models, we find that the loss drop that ends silent alignment is always accompanied by a growth in the sharpness to the final value of approximately 2/Î·2ğœ‚2/\eta2 / italic_Î·. We show this in Figure 4. This is the large Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ analogue of the progressive sharpening effect observed in Cohen et al. (2021). This effect is not present at small Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³.

4 A Simple Model Explaining Observed Scalings

In this section, we provide a theoretical model that explains all observed scaling relationships empirically observed in Figure 1 and analytically reproduces our phase portraits.

The following simple model will prove sufficient: a deep linear network of width one, trained on a single example. The network function in this case is fâ¢(x)=wLâ¢â€¦â¢w1â¢xğ‘“ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘¤ğ¿â€¦subscriptğ‘¤1ğ‘¥f(x)=w_{L}\dots w_{1}xitalic_f ( italic_x ) = italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â€¦ italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x. Critical learning rate for the catapult effect: The above one-parameter model is sufficient to obtain all the coarse dynamical phenomena we see except for so-called loss â€œcatapults.â€ As described by Lewkowycz et al. (2020), a network trained in the lazy regime with a just-too-large learning rate will grow quickly in loss, but then move to a flatter region of parameter space and converge.

The catapult effect generally requires two parameter dimensions to describe Damian et al. (2023), so our one-parameter model cannot capture it. In Appendix K, we describe and simulate a minimal two-parameter model that exhibits catapults. We find that for MSE loss, catapults occur in a narrow band Î·crit<Î·<Î·maxsubscriptğœ‚critğœ‚subscriptğœ‚\eta_{\text{crit}}<\eta<\eta_{\max}italic_Î· start_POSTSUBSCRIPT crit end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < italic_Î· < italic_Î· start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_max end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, with Î·critâˆ¼Î³2similar-tosubscriptğœ‚critsuperscriptğ›¾2\eta_{\text{crit}}\sim\gamma^{2}italic_Î· start_POSTSUBSCRIPT crit end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¼ italic_Î³ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT just like Î·maxsubscriptğœ‚max\eta_{\text{max}}italic_Î· start_POSTSUBSCRIPT max end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

The results, plotted in Figure 6, confirm our analytical scalings and match our phase portraits for deep networks (e.g. Figure 1).

5 Conclusion

We have presented a set of large-scale empirical sweeps across Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ for deep networks trained on realistic data. We have empirically identified how the upper bound for optimizable Î·ğœ‚\etaitalic_Î· is determined across a host of different Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ in terms of the training time and the depth of the network. We see that, conditional on an adjusted learning rate scaling with Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³, larger Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ NNs are competitive with or better than Î³=1ğ›¾1\gamma=1italic_Î³ = 1 NNs after training long enough. We have seen very predictable scaling of hessian spectra with Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ and identified various dynamical phenomena whose appearance is governed by the size of Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³. By appeal to a linear NN, we have been able to explain many of our observed scalings. In future steps, we hope to to extend our analysis to optimizers beyond SGD.

Author Contributions

AA ran early empirics that revealed the phase plot structure, initiating the project, ran all MNIST-1M and most CIFAR-5M experiments, wrote the initial draft, offered feedback on the solvable model, and led the team logistically. AM ran all ViT experiments and experiments on TinyImageNet, helped with CIFAR-5M experiments, observed the role of attention temperature in the final phase diagram, and offered technical feedback on both experimental and theoretical fronts. JS proposed and developed the solvable model exhibiting all phases, ran empirics on that model, and offered technical feedback on all experiments. CP supervised the project and gave feedback and direction. All authors contributed substantially to the final draft.

Appendix A Experimental Details

We evaluate all our experiments on A100 and H100 GPUs, using PyTorch. In order to compute the Hessian eigenvalues we use PyHessian Yao et al. (2020) evaluated on 1111 fixed batch of size 512512512512 at every point in time. In the following subsections we provide individual experimental details for every model trained.

Across all models, we swept over Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ from 10âˆ’5superscript10510^{-5}10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to 105superscript10510^{5}10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in a log-spacing with two samples per decade. We swept over Î·ğœ‚\etaitalic_Î· from 1010superscript101010^{10}10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 10 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT down to a lower limit that varied by experiment, as reported on the plots. For each run that caused a gradient explosion, the model was not saved. We only saved models with Î·ğœ‚\etaitalic_Î· less than or equal to the first convergent learning rate for each value of Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³. For the MNIST-1M plots and CIFAR-5M plots, at each value of Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ we only kept the seven values of Î·ğœ‚\etaitalic_Î· that are within a factor of 103superscript10310^{3}10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT from the top stable Î·ğœ‚\etaitalic_Î· to make the plots as in e.g. Figure 1.

In all cases, we created a CenteredModel class, ensuring that the output of the network is zero at initialization by making the following definition for the trained function f~~ğ‘“\tilde{f}over~ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG:

A.1 Comments on Numerical Stability in the Lazy Limit

Here we detail a ubiquitous problem that arose in the training of lazy neural networks at small Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³. To our knowledge, this problem has not been highlighted in the literature. At very small values of Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³, approximately 10âˆ’3superscript10310^{-3}10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, the appropriate learning rate in the lazy limit scales as Î·âˆ¼Î³2similar-toğœ‚superscriptğ›¾2\eta\sim\gamma^{2}italic_Î· âˆ¼ italic_Î³ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. This leads to weight updates on the order of 10âˆ’6superscript10610^{-6}10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 6 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT or less. Machine epsilon for float32 is near 10âˆ’7superscript10710^{-7}10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 7 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Because the final output of the function involves the subtraction in equation 10, the weight updates matter in both relative and absolute magnitude. For this reason, we find that we needed to go to double precision to reliably obtain curves below Î³=10âˆ’3ğ›¾superscript103\gamma=10^{-3}italic_Î³ = 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. In practice, we find that a value of Î³=10âˆ’3ğ›¾superscript103\gamma=10^{-3}italic_Î³ = 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT or even 10âˆ’2superscript10210^{-2}10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is essentially enough to reach the lazy limit in the online setting for essentially all tasks listed. See Appendix I.1 for a check of this.

We also highlight, that it is insufficient to simply zero out the last layer weights at initialization as a way to center the network. The lazy limit of a network with zero-initialized last layer weights yields the final-layer conjugate kernel or NNGP kernel. This kernel has very different properties from the NTK, especially in that its dimensionality scales as the width rather than the number of parameter of the network.

A.2 MNIST-1M

A diffusion model generated version of MNIST with 1 million images, which we will call MNIST-1M, was used to train these networks. We swept over a variety of widths, depths, batch sizes, and architectures. Each individual run took approximately 15 seconds on an A100 GPU. For each setting of width, depth, batch size, and architecture, we swept over the fine grid of Î³,Î·ğ›¾ğœ‚\gamma,\etaitalic_Î³ , italic_Î· stated above. This led to 7 runs per value of Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ or approximately 150150150150 runs total for each phase plot. Most runs were repeated over three initialization seeds, and key quantities, such as loss and accuracy, were seen to minimally vary over the initialization. This is expected in Î¼ğœ‡\muitalic_Î¼P, by arguments of approximate initialization independence at sufficiently large widths as in Bordelon & Pehlevan (2023); Mei et al. (2019).

The architectures we used were MLPs of depths 2,3,42342,3,42 , 3 , 4 and a feed-forward CNN of depth 4444 consisting of two convolutional and two feed-forward layers.

The corresponding test set for this dataset is the original MNIST test set.

Although it is quite easy for most networks to get to near 100 percent accuracy in one pass through this dataset, we believe that it fills an important gap in the space of datasets. It provides a task that is fast enough to learn, allowing for quick iteration, yet avoiding repetitions of data so as to remain online. In the era of online training, it is useful to have simple but large-scale datasets in order to test theory against. We do not claim that this dataset is representative of realistic imagenet scale natural data, but it is encouraging that virtually all effects observed in the CIFAR-5M and tinyimagenet datasets are also present in this smaller setting.

We observe that training accuracy on MNIST-1M meaningfully transfers to the original MNIST, and there is no observed overfitting effect in the networks that weâ€™ve trained.

A.3 CIFAR-10 and CIFAR-5M

We train on the full dataset of CIFAR-5M introduced in Nakkiran et al. (2021). This includes both the train set of 5 million images as well as the 1 million image test set, making for a total of 6 million images. We stay in the one pass setting. We also trained on CIFAR-10 with heavy data augmentation. We swept over width, depth, batch size, and architecture as above. In essentially all plots, we followed the same recipe for sweeping over Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ and Î·ğœ‚\etaitalic_Î·. For some of the ResNets and Vision transformers, larger sweeps were performed.

The architectures we used were feed-forward CNNs of depth 4444 as above, ResNets of varying depths as well as ResNet-18s, and Vision Transformers.

The corresponding test set for this dataset is the original CIFAR-10 test set.

A.4 TinyImageNet

In order to train on TinyImagenet in an online setting, we use random data augmentations: rotations and crops. All the experiments on this dataset have been run using batch size 128128128128. Individual architectural details are offered for every plot. We train all the models under Î¼â¢Pğœ‡ğ‘ƒ\mu Pitalic_Î¼ italic_P (or Depth-Î¼â¢Pğœ‡ğ‘ƒ\mu Pitalic_Î¼ italic_P where specified), using stochastic gradient descent (SGD).

Appendix B Review of NTK Parameterization and Î¼ğœ‡\muitalic_Î¼-Parameterization

For detailed discussion of Î¼ğœ‡\muitalic_Î¼P more generally, see Yang & Hu (2021); Yang et al. (2021); Geiger et al. (2020); Bordelon & Pehlevan (2022). The aim of this section is conceptual clarity on the difference between NTK parameterization and Î¼ğœ‡\muitalic_Î¼-parameterization, as well as to give some degree of motivation of the latter. See also the recent accessible works of Yang et al. (2023a) and Chizat & Netrapalli (2023).

There are several equivalent ways of parameterizing NNs that will yield the same dynamics as Î¼ğœ‡\muitalic_Î¼P. In what follows, we focus on a scalar-output feed-forward network for simplicity. The key distinction between NTK and Î¼ğœ‡\muitalic_Î¼ parameterizations it that the hidden layer activations move Î˜Nâ¢(1/N)subscriptÎ˜ğ‘1ğ‘\Theta_{N}(1/\sqrt{N})roman_Î˜ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 1 / square-root start_ARG italic_N end_ARG ) in the former and Î˜Nâ¢(1)subscriptÎ˜ğ‘1\Theta_{N}(1)roman_Î˜ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 1 ). One can straightforwardly extend the argument to more general architectures.

Appendix C Review of Dynamical Phenomena

In this section we review the essential dynamical phenomena studied in prior literature that arise in various regions of the Î·ğœ‚\etaitalic_Î·-Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ plane studied

C.1 Catapult Effect

The original catapult effect was studied in Lewkowycz et al. (2020). There, in the NTK parameterization, it was observed that at large but finite width, taking the learning rate Î·ğœ‚\etaitalic_Î· slightly above the bound given by convex optimization theory 2/Î»mâ¢aâ¢x2subscriptğœ†ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥2/\lambda_{max}2 / italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_a italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT led to a regime where the sharpness of the loss monotonically decreased. Follow up work has observed that the sharpness itself can undergo catapult behavior Kalra & Barkeshli (2023); Kalra et al. (2023). In Bordelon & Pehlevan (2023) it was argued and shown that in Î¼ğœ‡\muitalic_Î¼P, one can observe catapults even at infinite width.

C.2 Silent Alignment

In Atanasov et al. (2022), it was argued that linear neural networks trained on whitened data starting from small initialization undergo an alignment of their weights in the task-relevant direction before their function output scale has grown sufficiently. The kernel alignment thus grows well before a loss drop, indicating that even at a loss plateau, the NN has learned a meaningful representation of the data. The results were empirically tested on a relatively small class of more realistic tasks. Here, we extend the class of tasks, and observe silent alignment phenomena for nonlinear networks on realistic and anisotropic tasks.

C.3 Edge of Stability

In Cohen et al. (2021), in the setting of full-batch gradient descent, it was observed that the maximum hessian eigenvalue grew to the scale of 2/Î·2ğœ‚2/\eta2 / italic_Î·, where it stabilized. This effect was further studied in Damian et al. (2023). In the SGD setting, a similar effect persists, though the final sharpness is modified from the 2/Î·2ğœ‚2/\eta2 / italic_Î· limit to something that depends more holistically on the spectrum. See Agarwala et al. (2022) for a theoretical study and discussion in this setting.

Appendix D A Two-Parameter Model Recovering Catapult Scalings

In this appendix, we describe a two-parameter model which recovers our main phase portrait and â€” unlike the one-parameter model of Section 4 â€” exhibits true catapult behavior with just-too-large learning rates in the lazy regime. We will first give an analytical treatment, then conclude with simulations.

Our model and argument will be very similar to those used by Lewkowycz et al. (2020), but with a slightly different focus: rather than examining the effect of the width Nğ‘Nitalic_N on catapult behavior, we study how the Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ parameter controls catapult behavior. When width and Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ are properly disentangled (that is, when one uses Î¼ğœ‡\muitalic_Î¼P), the width of the network plays no role in determining catapults. Indeed, recent work Bordelon & Pehlevan (2023) has shown that deep networks can catapult even at infinite width. The catapult effect does not happen at large Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³, so we will ultimately focus on small Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³.

D.2 Cross-entropy loss

As with the one-parameter model of Section 4, we may also train our two-parameter model with the binary cross-entropy loss given in Equation 9. The dynamics for cross-entropy loss are substantially more difficult to analyze than those for MSE â€” in fact, as noted by Meng et al. (2024), even an ordinary linear model trained with cross-entropy loss will exhibit chaotic dynamic in certain parameter regimes! In actual fact, the dynamics are quite similar, scaling-wise, to those for MSE, except in a critical â€œcatapult triangleâ€ in the lazy regime in which Î·crit<Î·<Î·maxsubscriptğœ‚critğœ‚subscriptğœ‚max\eta_{\text{crit}}<\eta<\eta_{\text{max}}italic_Î· start_POSTSUBSCRIPT crit end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < italic_Î· < italic_Î· start_POSTSUBSCRIPT max end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, where Î·critâˆ¼Î³2similar-tosubscriptğœ‚critsuperscriptğ›¾2\eta_{\text{crit}}\sim\gamma^{2}italic_Î· start_POSTSUBSCRIPT crit end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¼ italic_Î³ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and Î·maxâˆ¼Î³similar-tosubscriptğœ‚ğ›¾\eta_{\max}\sim\gammaitalic_Î· start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_max end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¼ italic_Î³. Recall that our one-parameter model neither converged nor diverged in this regime. Our two-parameter model begins to show similar behavior, but, after sufficiently long training time, bounces to a different part of the loss landscape and converges. The dynamics here are similar to the catapult dynamics described by Damian et al. (2023), except that the â€œunstable directionâ€ sees a straight-walled loss basin instead of a quadratic basin (think â„’â¢(x)=|x|â„’ğ‘¥ğ‘¥\mathcal{L}(x)=|x|caligraphic_L ( italic_x ) = | italic_x | instead of â„’â¢(x)=x2â„’ğ‘¥superscriptğ‘¥2\mathcal{L}(x)=x^{2}caligraphic_L ( italic_x ) = italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT). We anticipate an analytical treatment in the style of Damian et al. (2023) would be elucidating, but it could make up a substantial part of a paper in and of itself, so at this point we turn to numerics.

D.3 Simulations of the two-parameter toy model

We numerically simulate our two-parameter model for both loss functions considered. For MSE, we train for T=103ğ‘‡superscript103T=10^{3}italic_T = 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT steps. For cross-entropy, we train for Tâ‰ˆ3Ã—104ğ‘‡3superscript104T\approx 3\times 10^{4}italic_T â‰ˆ 3 Ã— 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT steps to give the dynamics in the â€œcatapult triangleâ€ more time to converge.

The results are shown in Figures 8 and 9. We plot both the final loss and the maximum loss at any point in training. In both cases, we see phase portraits very similar to those for our one-parameter model (Figure 6), but we also see the loss exploding before convergence in the catapult phase.

Appendix E Additional ResNet and ViT Plots

Here we supplement the Î·ğœ‚\etaitalic_Î·-Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ phase plots in the main text with additional plots across different architectures and datasets. We report results for ResNets and visiont transformers. Across all settings, we recover the phase portraits sketched out in Figures 1.

Appendix F Effect of width and check of Î¼ğœ‡\muitalic_Î¼-consistency

In this section we provide checks of Î¼ğœ‡\muitalic_Î¼P working. We do this by both plotting in Figure 13 and Figure 14 as well as their CNN and croseentropy analogues. We observe the following:

  • â€¢

    The loss curves as a function of time across widths begin to match as Nğ‘Nitalic_N grows, confirming that they are converging to an â€œinfinite widthâ€ loss curve

  • â€¢

    The performance vs the learning rate Î·ğœ‚\etaitalic_Î· across width is stable, as expected in Î¼ğœ‡\muitalic_Î¼P.

Importantly, as a consequence of consistency across widths at sufficiently large Nğ‘Nitalic_N, one does not need to additionally vary the width parameter in order to exhaustively sweep out the space of feature learning NNs.

F.1 Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³-dependency of Î¼ğœ‡\muitalic_Î¼-consistency

Here, we study to what extent width-consistency is violated as a function of Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³.

Appendix G Effect of depth

In this section we vary the depth Lğ¿Litalic_L for both feed-forward MLPs and for ResNets. In the MLP setting, we find a straightforward change in the Î·âˆ’Î³ğœ‚ğ›¾\eta-\gammaitalic_Î· - italic_Î³ plane. In the rich regime, the maximal observable learning rate scales as Î³2/Lsuperscriptğ›¾2ğ¿\gamma^{2/L}italic_Î³ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 / italic_L end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, consistent with our model in 4.

G.1 MLPs

G.2 ResNets and Depth-Î¼ğœ‡\muitalic_Î¼P

In this section we test the effect of the parameterization on deep neural networks with residual connections. Specifically, in Figure 22 and Figure 21 we evaluate the phase plots of neural networks with increasing depths parameterized in Depth-Î¼ğœ‡\muitalic_Î¼P, as detailed in Bordelon et al. (2023); Yang et al. (2023b), and Î¼ğœ‡\muitalic_Î¼P.

Appendix H Effect of batch size

In this section, we verify that in the online limit, different batch sizes have a relatively negligible effect on the dynamics. The batch noise does however make it so that smaller batches cause higher variance in the loss. This is the tradeoff for being able to train to a lower loss at fixed dataset.

Appendix L Kernel-Target Alignment

The associated kernel-target alignment is given by:

KTAâ¢(K,ğ’š)â‰¡ğ’šâŠ¤â¢Kâ¢ğ’šâ€–Kâ€–â¢|ğ’š|2.KTAğ¾ğ’šsuperscriptğ’štopğ¾ğ’šnormğ¾superscriptğ’š2\mathrm{KTA}(K,\bm{y})\equiv\frac{\bm{y}^{\top}K\bm{y}}{\|K\||\bm{y}|^{2}}.roman_KTA ( italic_K , bold_italic_y ) â‰¡ divide start_ARG bold_italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K bold_italic_y end_ARG start_ARG âˆ¥ italic_K âˆ¥ | bold_italic_y | start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG . (19)

Here â€–Kâ€–normğ¾\|K\|âˆ¥ italic_K âˆ¥ is some appropriate norm of the kernel matrix. There are many options, including Frobenius norm, operator norm (maximum singular value), and nuclear norm (sum of singular values). The alignment during the loss plateau is quite sensitive to the choice of norm on Kğ¾Kitalic_K,. In practice, weâ€™ve found that the nuclear norm produces the best results, with Frobenius and Operator norm metrics sometimes resulting in a dip of the alignment before the loss drop rather than a growth.

A related quantity, centered kernel alignment (CKA) Cortes et al. (2012), has been argued in Kornblith et al. (2019) to be a good candidate for the comparison of neural representations. In practice, we found direct CKA measures between NTKs of different networks to be very noisy and sensitive. CKA on hidden layer activations yielded more reliable plots.
